title: Twinkie insanity hits the House
authors: Marion Nestle, Larry Cohen, Rob Waters
content:
The U.S. is in the midst of an epidemic of poor health , the authors write . Twinkie insanity hits the House
Rep. Aaron Schock ( R-Ill. ) argued in ███ April 17 that it should be illegal for the U.S. government ’ s public health guardian — the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention — to point out to children and their parents that Twinkies and sugar-laced sodas are bad for health .
In his op-ed , Schock expresses concern that federal money is being used by local health agencies to “ attack … Americans ’ freedom of choice ” when they point out that such products have little nutritional value , and contribute to the exploding rates of diabetes and other chronic disease . His solution : Muzzle the CDC and the community agencies they support .
When local health agencies ask children and teenagers to commit to a “ soda-free summer , ” Schock calls such campaigns “ propaganda. ” He wants to bar federal money from supporting them . His bill seeks to ban federal support for any “ media advertisement , campaign or form of publicity against the use of a food or beverage that is lawfully marketed . ”
Soda is the number one source of sugar in the American diet and a growing body of evidence demonstrates that sugar-sweetened beverages are among the most significant contributors to diseases related to obesity . These beverages accounted for 43 percent of the increase in daily calories consumed between 1977 and 2001 , according to research published in 2010 .
In 2009 , according to a recent report by the U.S. Trade Commission , the food industry spent $ 1.8 billion advertising food products to children . In 2010 , the U.S. beverage industry alone spent $ 948 million advertising sugary drinks to children , according to data compiled by Yale University ’ s Rudd Center for Food Policy and Obesity . Soda industry ad campaigns , created by psychologists and marketing experts , use figures like SpongeBob SquarePants , lovable rabbits , and sports and entertainment celebrities to influence our kids .
It ’ s difficult for us to believe that Schock seriously thinks that these billion-dollar companies and their Madison Ave. advertising agencies require protection from public health advocates who point out that Froot Loops and supersized sodas are bad for kids ’ health .
Schock argues that health campaigns aimed at informing the public about the dangers of consuming too much of these products will kill jobs in our communities at a time of high unemployment . This is a specious argument . It assumes that jobs can ’ t also result from creating healthy products instead of unhealthy ones . Schock seems to be making an argument similar to one that says campaigns against cigarettes shouldn ’ t occur because they destroy the jobs of tobacco growers .
Schock writes that government agencies shouldn ’ t be “ telling Americans not to eat Twinkies at a time when the federal government is running trillion-dollar deficits. ” But this is precisely the time we should be advising people not to eat foods that might be bad for their health . One of the biggest contributors to the deficit is the exploding cost of treating preventable chronic diseases like diabetes and heart disease , conditions closely linked to what we eat .
The U.S. — along with virtually every country in the world where people ’ s diets have come to be dominated by high-sugar , high-fat processed foods and beverages — is in the midst of an epidemic of poor health liked to poor diets and inadequate physical activity . The only way out of this unhealthy mess , and the cost it imposes on us as a nation , is to change our habits and practices . Many businesses understand this and are strong advocates for their workers and communities , as is the military .
The real propaganda comes from companies that market sugar-sweetened breakfast cereals as healthful . The job of the Centers for Disease Control ’ s is to assess the key threats to our health and assure that people have the best , most accurate information possible . That ’ s not propaganda ; it ’ s public service .
Marion Nestle , Paulette Goddard Professor in the Department of Nutrition , Food Studies , and Public Health at New York University ; Larry Cohen , founder and executive director of Prevention Institute , an Oakland , California-based nonprofit organization that works nationally to promote prevention , health and wellness ; Rob Waters , chief communications officer of Prevention Institute .
content_original:
The U.S. is in the midst of an epidemic of poor health, the authors write. Twinkie insanity hits the House

Rep. Aaron Schock (R-Ill.) argued in POLITICO April 17 that it should be illegal for the U.S. government’s public health guardian — the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention — to point out to children and their parents that Twinkies and sugar-laced sodas are bad for health.

In his op-ed, Schock expresses concern that federal money is being used by local health agencies to “attack … Americans’ freedom of choice” when they point out that such products have little nutritional value, and contribute to the exploding rates of diabetes and other chronic disease. His solution: Muzzle the CDC and the community agencies they support.

Advertisement

When local health agencies ask children and teenagers to commit to a “soda-free summer,” Schock calls such campaigns “propaganda.” He wants to bar federal money from supporting them. His bill seeks to ban federal support for any “media advertisement, campaign or form of publicity against the use of a food or beverage that is lawfully marketed.”

This bill ignores some basic realities.

Soda is the number one source of sugar in the American diet and a growing body of evidence demonstrates that sugar-sweetened beverages are among the most significant contributors to diseases related to obesity. These beverages accounted for 43 percent of the increase in daily calories consumed between 1977 and 2001, according to research published in 2010.

In 2009, according to a recent report by the U.S. Trade Commission, the food industry spent $1.8 billion advertising food products to children. In 2010, the U.S. beverage industry alone spent $948 million advertising sugary drinks to children, according to data compiled by Yale University’s Rudd Center for Food Policy and Obesity. Soda industry ad campaigns, created by psychologists and marketing experts, use figures like SpongeBob SquarePants, lovable rabbits, and sports and entertainment celebrities to influence our kids.

It’s difficult for us to believe that Schock seriously thinks that these billion-dollar companies and their Madison Ave. advertising agencies require protection from public health advocates who point out that Froot Loops and supersized sodas are bad for kids’ health.

Schock argues that health campaigns aimed at informing the public about the dangers of consuming too much of these products will kill jobs in our communities at a time of high unemployment. This is a specious argument. It assumes that jobs can’t also result from creating healthy products instead of unhealthy ones. Schock seems to be making an argument similar to one that says campaigns against cigarettes shouldn’t occur because they destroy the jobs of tobacco growers.

Schock writes that government agencies shouldn’t be “telling Americans not to eat Twinkies at a time when the federal government is running trillion-dollar deficits.” But this is precisely the time we should be advising people not to eat foods that might be bad for their health. One of the biggest contributors to the deficit is the exploding cost of treating preventable chronic diseases like diabetes and heart disease, conditions closely linked to what we eat.

The U.S. — along with virtually every country in the world where people’s diets have come to be dominated by high-sugar, high-fat processed foods and beverages — is in the midst of an epidemic of poor health liked to poor diets and inadequate physical activity. The only way out of this unhealthy mess, and the cost it imposes on us as a nation, is to change our habits and practices. Many businesses understand this and are strong advocates for their workers and communities, as is the military.

The real propaganda comes from companies that market sugar-sweetened breakfast cereals as healthful. The job of the Centers for Disease Control’s is to assess the key threats to our health and assure that people have the best, most accurate information possible. That’s not propaganda; it’s public service.

Marion Nestle, Paulette Goddard Professor in the Department of Nutrition, Food Studies, and Public Health at New York University; Larry Cohen, founder and executive director of Prevention Institute, an Oakland, California-based nonprofit organization that works nationally to promote prevention, health and wellness; Rob Waters, chief communications officer of Prevention Institute.
